body.note: The Tournament of Salisbury

The version of RCL contained in Harley MS 4690 begins on fol. 109r in the second/right-hand column. The first column and the preceding folio are blank, and this particular witness of RCL begins mid-sentence and midway through the Tournament of Salisbury episode. This particular witness is remarkable in that it is placed into a prose chronicle (The Prose Brut) to account for this particular part of English history.

Our ffoukedol&ydot; soche a stroke he sette
body.note: explain who this and Thomas Multon are and acknowledge the spelling variations of Fouk's name. Supplying Larkin’s note here for now since we’ll want to draw on it and Finlayson, who he references: 399 Fouke Doly. Of undoubted historicity, Fulk D’Oilly and Thomas Moulton (line 433) were Lincolnshire knights connected by marriage in the thirteenth century. As they do not appear in chronicles of the Third Crusade, Finalyson suggests that the large role these knights play in RCL’s a version represents an early redactor’s efforts “to glorify his or a patron’s family,” since the names do not occur in L, the fragment that Finlayson believes to contain the story’s basic form (“‘Richard, Coer de Lyon,’” p. 166; and “Legendary Ancestors”) (METS RCL, n. 399)

body.note: The journey that Richard, Thomas, and Fouk agree to embark upon in this episode is a fiction. Richard never undertook such a journey prior to going to Outremer on crusade.
body.l: whe thre felaues and no mo
Al in palmeren g&ydot;se
body.note: The term "palmer" referred specifically to a pilgrim bound for Jerusalem. The term referred to the particular badge that such a pilgrim would wear as a sign of their intended destination; pilgrim's bound for Jerusalem wore a palm badge that recalled Christ's celebrated entry into Jerusalem prior to his crucifixion. The term "guise" here, however, makes it very clear that Richard and his fellow knights are not intending for this journey to be a pious one. They are, instead, disguising themselves as pilgrims in order to embark on a reconaissance mission that will aid them in their later crusading endeavors.

Also of note, perhaps, is that unlike other witnesses, the rhyme scheme is broken between the lines ending with Cesare and Jerusalem because there appears to be a “missing” line. Brunner, in fact, writes “fehlt” (i.e. “is missing”) in his note for this line (pg. 111, n. 638), which in other versions refers to the city of Nineva and ends with the word “ware.” Based on the break in rhyme, this is very likely an eye-skip on the part of the copyist.

body.note: Richard, Thomas, and Fouk arrive in Germany.

This episode, which recounts Richard's imprisonment by the king of Germany, is largely a fiction. While the historical King Richard was imprisoned in Germany, this occurred on his return from crusade, not before it. To the best of our knowledge, the historical Richard did not kill the king's son, sleep with the king's daughter, and kill a lion with his bare hands while a prisoner.

The flourish appears similar to ꝯ the Latin small letter for the 'con' abbreviation or  the baseline abbreviation, though the word itself does not seem contextually abbreviated. The flourish could also be an antisigma to reorder the line, which could make sense if the glyph before [grym] were an & or abbreviation for Richard, though we doubt those possibilities given the preceding words, so we believe the flourish does not carry lexical meaning.
